157511658.review:
I'm 46. I've been gaming since I was about 3, when my dad brought home our first Atari 2600. 

I own over 700 PC games. We have all three of the major consoles. I have never played any game as much as I've played Satisfactory. 

I play alone. I play with my wife. I play with my kids. I've listened to probably half a dozen audiobooks while playing. 

I have 1,427.5 hours in the game currently, and that's with roughly 6 month breaks between games. 

I could talk about the mechanics, the building, the exploration, but other reviewers have done that. I'm here to say that the experience is a 10/10. I'm so familiar with the world, that wherever I am, I can pop into the game and feel like I'm home. 

Satisfactory is a masterpiece.

160707070.review:
Been playing for years and only just realized I never gave it a like. That's how addictive this thing is. So here I am, over 1500 game hours later and honestly I'm not sure where to even start. 

The graphics are really great. You get a sense of wonder and awe as you explore across an alien world trying to figure out where to place your next machine. While sometimes you may have to deal with local wildlife, it is not much beyond that. Pollution is not taken into account so you can pave the entire planet with asphalt and concrete and cover it with drones and trains until your frame rate tanks. Which by the way, will take you quite a long while. The game is optimized pretty well at this point already. Never had I had so much joy in using so many machines to suck out the resources of a planet to not only serve the bosses at Ficsit, but to create my dream base of epic sizes. Right after I cover that crash of a previous pioneer with concrete >cough<

You will see for yourself, the only thing that matters is the factory and the FACTORY MUST GROW. ;)

If you even think you would like a factory style game in which you exploit a planet, this is it hands down. The devs have been completely transparent, honest, upfront about everything they will and won't do. Because of that you always know that the game never strays from what it is. I believe they are the best in the business and are a shining example of what Game companys SHOULD be. The game is almost out to 1.0 as of this review and it's the first and only game that I will be sad to see get finished.

158044339.review:
A very good game, although I'm not quite as enthusiastic about it as some of its most ardent supporters.

My main criticism of Satisfactory is that a lot of what's in there seems to be aimed mainly at stretching out play time: you'll spend a lot of time in this game waiting for things, no matter how much you optimize the various processes it involves. Don't get me wrong - there are people who like this kind of thing, who think it adds "depth" to a game, but to me, a lot of this stuff could be done faster - the game would still be long enough, just less tedious, which is surely a good thing.

I also find myself wishing that the game were more procedural - that the world was different each time you played. It wouldn't have to be much more than just randomizing where the resources were - but as it stands, it seems to me that it has quite limited replayability.

Those grizzles aside, though, it's a very pretty and amusing game, and remarkably reliable given that it's early-access. If you like building things and don't mind doing a bit of simple maths to work out optimizations, this game might be one of the best of its kind at the moment.

Recommended.

After dedicating 33 hours to Satisfactory on Steam, 
I've reached a juncture where my preferred playstyle presents challenges to my enjoyment. 
While labeling it "unplayable" might be overstating it, having delved into similar simulation games in the past, 
I embarked on a mission for complete automation. 
This involved meticulously orchestrating every aspect, utilizing splitters and storage boxes for optimum resource management. 

This endeavor swiftly escalated into a maze of energy consumption and intricate calculations, 
necessitating grids, notes, and even resorting to traditional pen and paper. 
As I painstakingly crafted my automated systems i found myself perpetually torn between progress and the compulsion to dismantle and reconstruct for greater efficiency.

[h3]Despite these hurdles, it's crucial to underscore the sheer brilliance of Satisfactory.[/h3]
From the instant i launched the game, was enraptured by its potential. 
I wholeheartedly endorse it for anyone who relishes the complexities of automation and simulation games. 
My struggles with the game are attributable to my specific playstyle and inclination towards perfectionism, rather than any inherent flaw in the game itself.

[i]Furthermore, impressed by the graphics, hotkeys, and game settings, which all contributed to enhancing the overall experience.[/i]

161840752.review:
In the ever-expanding landscape of simulation games, Satisfactory emerges as a true gem, offering an unparalleled experience in the realm of industrial construction and resource management. Developed by Coffee Stain Studios, this game transcends the boundaries of traditional sandbox gameplay, inviting players on an exhilarating journey of exploration, innovation, and automation.

Gameplay Mechanics:
At its core, Satisfactory revolves around the meticulous design and optimization of vast industrial complexes. From humble beginnings as a lone pioneer on an alien planet, players embark on a quest to harness its resources and build a thriving civilization. The game's first-person perspective adds an immersive touch, allowing you to witness the fruits of your labor firsthand as you traverse the sprawling landscapes and marvel at your towering creations.

Resource Management:
One of Satisfactory's most compelling aspects is its intricate resource management system. Every tree felled, every ore mined, and every machine constructed plays a crucial role in the grand scheme of your operation. Balancing the needs of your growing colony against the finite resources of the planet becomes a delicate dance, requiring careful planning and strategic foresight.

Factory Optimization:
Where Satisfactory truly shines is in its emphasis on automation and efficiency. As you unlock new technologies and production methods, you'll find yourself designing ever more complex factory layouts, complete with intricate conveyor belt networks and automated machinery. The satisfaction of watching your meticulously crafted production lines churn out goods at an astonishing rate is unmatched, driving you to constantly refine and optimize your designs for peak performance.

Exploration and Discovery:
Beyond the confines of your factory walls, Satisfactory offers a vast and diverse world ripe for exploration. From verdant forests to treacherous deserts, each biome presents its own unique challenges and opportunities. Venturing into the unknown, you'll uncover hidden resources, encounter exotic wildlife, and unravel the mysteries of the alien planet, all while expanding your influence and securing your foothold in this untamed frontier.

Visuals and Atmosphere:
Visually, Satisfactory is a feast for the senses. The vibrant, stylized graphics breathe life into the alien landscapes, while the dynamic lighting and environmental effects add a layer of immersion rarely seen in sandbox games. Coupled with a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that shifts seamlessly between moments of tranquil introspection and pulse-pounding action, Satisfactory succeeds in creating a world that feels both alien and familiar, inviting players to lose themselves in its wonders.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Satisfactory stands as a testament to the limitless potential of the sandbox genre. With its deep gameplay mechanics, breathtaking visuals, and immersive atmosphere, it offers an experience that is as rewarding as it is addictive. While not without its challenges, the sheer joy of building, exploring, and innovating in this alien world is an experience that every gamer owes it to themselves to discover. Satisfactory is more than just a game; it's a journey into the future of industrial innovation, and it's one that you won't soon forget.

It all began innocently enough. I fired up *Satisfactory*, expecting a quaint factory-building escapade. But oh, how wrong I was! The loading screen winked at me like a mischievous quasar, whispering, “Prepare to lose your sanity, Captain.”

🌠 **The World of MASSAGE-2 (A-B)b: Where Nuts and Bolts Dream of Stardom**

🔧 **The Factory: A Symphony of Screws and Regret**

I built my base on a floating island, because why not? Gravity is for conformists. My factory sprawled like a caffeinated octopus, churning out widgets, gizmos, and existential dread. 161776758.review:
Ok. So with my nearly 1000 hours of game time in this game at the time of writing this review I hope that my 2 brain cells will help some new players as the game prepares to leave out of early access. 
This game I will rate as a solid 9/10 stars overall. Why? oh just you wait. ill tell you all the things!

DEV TEAM
First of all. I usually don't have much of an opinion on DEV teams, I usually find them.... underwhelming and lacking in communication with the game community. But! This team has managed to stay informed with all the bugs and glitches in the game and also kept us in the community informed so well that I have never really had any issues paying for this game the one time. and it goes on sale from time to time too! 
It is not often that I find such a refreshing team that is left to build an awesome game with no issues in understanding that we in the community have lives to live. on top of that just when I start to wonder when the next update will drop there is usually a post about it somewhere. There is not many games that I would buy more than one copy for but this is one of them.

~They keep us well informed on various platforms like on, "https://www.youtube.com/@CoffeeStainStudios"
~They worked hard on this game and still put it on sale unlike another factory game out there.
~and while they don't have and wont be offering official modding support, they still love the modding community too!
~They are mindful of players in the game and try their best to give the community what is asked and are honest when they wont or cant do something.

GAME-PLAY
First of all, if you are the kind of gamer that requires quest/object flags to tell you what to do constantly, you will really struggle with this game. 
The game is a wonderful open world game with plenty of areas to bulldoze and build on-top of to your hearts content. BUT. to be clear, you can not change the terrain at all in the game. Some rocks, trees, and other objects are destructible but there is no large scale terraforming in Satisfactory.
The game while buggy at times or laggy/glitcy is understandable in the more recent months. If you watch some of their videos you will find out that they rather recently updated to a newer game engine to help give the players the best experience come 1.0 release. So with that in mind keep in mind that bugs and the like will happen here and there till the game leaves early access some time late this year (2024) or so if plans stay on track. 

PROGRESSION 
~The point of satisfactory is to have an open world experience without a game telling you how to do things or go about doing something. You get a few tips and tricks early on in game during the on-boarding tutorial of the game that will help teach you the important stuff of the game. However, it is entirely up to you on how you build your factory. there are many ways to build a production line. Starting off you may find yourself wondering around not sure where to place your base and factories, but you can deconstruct with no worry of needing more stuff to build those things again. Make it perfect or sloppy as hecc!
~Satisfactory gives you the player control of how much effort you want to go. if you want to min/max EVERYTHING, You can!
if you want to do the bare minimum, you can!
~To be honest. This video is a great source of what I mean. Give it a listen or watch https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kq_IklMd0Mc&t

Honestly there is so much to be said about this game that is good about it. and while there are also many things that could be made better, I think what we have is a dang good start for a one of a kind 3D factory game like this. Sure there are others but none of them seem to have the amount of care as satisfactory. 
This game will make you think, you may have to do some math. but I think this game at the very least helps keep me from losing one of my last two brain-cells. who knows. But I really think this game belongs in all education systems! it could be a powerful learning tool.

If anyone has any questions drop a comment below and I will respond to them when I am able. but I really think that Satisfactory offers a little of something for everyone. Give it a chance. give it like 10 hours. Its a big game with a big picture to see. but its up to you to discover and paint it.

I'm sure it will be a great game, it is really addicting and satis...factory... but it still is in early access. 

-Fluid mechanics are very bugged (if you have "slushing"(?) mechanics in pipelines, you really also need to implement viscosity, or forget those and just make it work properly (fluids are "taking turns" in junctions)).
-There is lot of unpolished issues remaining, that will make you feel like playing a game instead of living another life in another place. 
-It's really frustrating to fight the mechanics, when you know what you want to accomplish, but need to figure out how those mechanics let you build what you were planning. 
-Clipping issues I don't mind, other than it feels like cheating to build conveyors through walls and such. Also breaks the immersion.

+Progress is in my opinion spot on. 
+Nice quality of life gadgets and stuff
+It is beautiful
+There's always some improvement project to tackle and it always feels good to untangle that conveyor mess
+You do you, whatever you like

It is really enjoyable as it is, but I would still wait for full release, as it is still also rather frustrating.

Satisfactory is a real gem for fans of construction and management games. Its unique concept, combining exploration, resource exploitation and the construction of complex factories on an alien planet, offers an immersive and exciting experience. The freedom offered to players in the design and organization of their factories allows limitless creativity.

The stunning graphics and beautifully designed open world add to the immersion, inspiring players to explore every corner of the planet to exploit its resources. The game's progression is perfectly balanced, providing a constant challenge while maintaining a feeling of gratification with each milestone achieved.

Multiplayer co-op allows you to share this experience with friends, further enhancing the social side of the game and providing interesting collaboration opportunities. The active and passionate community also helps enrich the experience through mods and shared creations.

In summary, Satisfactory is an exceptional game that brilliantly succeeds in combining exploration, management and construction in a captivating open world. Its rich and immersive gameplay makes it an unforgettable experience for any lover of construction and management games.

Satisfactory is a resource management and logistics / distribution simulator.

How do you feel about spending a few hours building a split conveyor belt network and doing maths on pen and paper to make sure your input machines are all running at 100% capacity?

It is NOT A GAME. It is an unpaid part time job. 

11/10. Brilliant.

160594364.review: This game is crazy good. Single or Multiplayer. - Over 50 Researches to overcome by exploring and crafting weapons

- Developed with constant feedback from and to the passionate community

It is subjectively the best automation game I know. There is a lot to say about the game, because it is pretty complex in the later phases of the game, but to keep it short I just have to say that this game is pretty much THE best example of how early access games have to be. The first time I saw someone play the game I thought it was"meh", but when I tried it out myself I was baffled how much time you pass in the game without noticing it. You think to yourself "Oh I am gonna quickly build that production line" and boom a couple of hours go by like 5 minutes. And the satisfaction you get when you're optimizing your factories or roads or conveyor belts or electricity etc. is insane.

I recommend the game, to everyone who wants to deep dive into game mechanics and a little bit of math in terms of opimization and of course to people who like to see things happen in front of them instead of only numbers on some spreadsheets. The game is easily worth double the price it has right now. (30 euros)

159344568.review:
As of now yes you should buy this game, butttttt... Don't go into this expecting big end game rewards. I was hoping I would get to fly, swim, anything. Something marvelous. No you're reward for doing all that work and grinding is just more work and grinding. Is the core loop addictive and fun? Yes, but I can't help this hollow feeling in my chest that the only thing I can explore after all that work is just... More flat planes and jagged fucked up parts of the map. 

Tip to the devs you need to work on your map MUCH more (reward exploration more and make it easier to build good looking structures) same thing with rewards for player progression. You've nailed your factory game play, but everything else is hollow and lacking. It's like if the only thing you could do in subnautica is build stuff and swim around. No sense of danger or real exploration at all. 

Hey you don't have to put enemies in the game (the enemies in the game now are dog butt because they insta aggro and teleport 70 feet into the air to randomly demolish you while you're building) Use the environment to challenge us. For instance there's a massive river in a crater in the middle of the map. That gave me a real challenge to work around so I could get to the dense coal patches located in it. 

Use mountains, rivers, lakes, heck even resource limitations to challenge us as players.

Anyway looking forward to where this game will go in the future especially if my advice is taken into consideration.

158877888.review:
I've said before that the best video games tend to be the ones that give the feeling of achievement when accomplishing tasks - this game takes that to the extreme. This brilliant and huge game will have you feeling more pride than you wish your parents had in you. Constant micro-successes in a progression-based game that constantly keep you in a state of "moving forward" and being engaged. 
Survival/Combat: The survival/fighting starts of negligible while you're first starting out, but scales up as you go as you have to overcome some beasties to get what you need in the later game - but by then you can build very fun weapons to deal with it. The survival element as a whole is very welcome and adds more to the game, without being a particular focus.
Exploration: 10/10, the map is absolutely HUGE and all of it is so interesting to explore. No matter how big your inventory gets, you'll wish for more space so you can explore the whole world and scavenge everything on your way for the MAM!
Construction/Creativity: 11/10, your imagination is the limit! I've seen games dedicated to designing bases that have less options and flexibility as this game. You can make basically anything to fit whatever aesthetic you like. I've seen people make decorative cathedral-like structures, and others make industrial apocalypse style grinders.
The "Factory" grind element: 11/10, the problem solving, streamlining, and progression is just fantastic. There's so much more to this game than just "the grind" that you almost forget about it, and the grind itself is satisfying as heck.
Replay-ability: 9/10. Most people can get MANY do-overs on this game to last them years. Starting in a different location alone changes the first like 30 hours of gameplay. I could see myself, solo, restarting a few times before even needing to set my own challenges for the game, and still enjoying it.

Note RE Single VS Multiplayer: I started off this game on my own in the basic spawn area. I enjoyed it so much and sunk so many hours in whenever I could and I enjoyed it all SO much. However, I personally think there comes a few points in the mid-game where "the grind" is a bit much for one person, and I think it's apparent this game was intended to be best played with at least one other person. Like Minecraft, you'll have a great time on your own, but this goes up to an 11 (maybe even a 12) out of 10 with a friend or two.

158643956.review:
I was on the fence for quit a bit with Satisfactory and now? Wish I would of bought it a LOT SOONER!

What isn't there to like? I could make this review a LOT shorter if I only point out it's shortcomings as there isn't much to bash this game with. Is it hard? Yes and no but it will definitely get your old noodle thinking. So lets start off with the obvious.

The game is beautiful, extremely LARGE MAP and a LOT of details have been but into this game. Unfortunately this means you will have to have a decent rig to play this game in it's full beauty. The flexibility this game gives you to remold this world is staggering and the best point of this game? You can play it as YOU see fit but I won't say this game STAYS easy as the goals in the game keep getting raised in the most surprising way. PRODUCTIVITY! And the key to productivity? Figuring out HOW to fully auto-mate your factories where you DON'T need to be there 24/7 for them to keep working as you keep upgrading your tools to maximize production because halfway through the game? You are delivering products with multiple complex parts that need to be assembled in mass. You CAN assemble 90% in this game yourself BUT there will be a massive time penalty as that is what you will be stuck doing the majority of the time... for HOURS. This game will easily eat up DAYS of your time as you figure out what works, what doesn't and usually? Starting over when things become too much of a mess and you plan out your next restart. There's little tricks you eventually figure out as you play the game and here's my biggest hint, leave room for expansion. Those veins you mine for ore? Those drills will eventually be upgraded to double the output so? Plan for it, put a belt splitter you don't need NOW for later. Of course there's other people who can make factories so tight and efficient? Making me look like I'm still taking baby steps which? Doesn't matter as long as I'm enjoying the game.

The thing I like most about this game? There is never any pressure to play save the pressure you put on yourself and dying is actually hard to do as long as you don't get reckless but there ARE a few dangerous enemies that WILL chase you down once you run across them but run, run! RUN!! usually works if you don't stick around TRYING to kill them. Odd note? Once you get your vehicle, save for the hachers, ALL enemies actually ignore you in a vehicle and the hachers actually can't damage the vehicle which YOU don't take damage as long as your driving. Even those deadly enemies that chase you down. There is also specific tools that are extremely useful in building that the game never touches on. Too many to list but go on YouTube to find them yourself. This is a pretty deep game that isn't here just to kill you but if you push your luck? It doesn't have a problem killing stupid.

So this is a very fun game that WILL bog you down with massive orders and ironically, even opening up your tech tree is going to cost you a lot of processed materials. I was a little slow on the uptake but? Soon as you have a new piece to make? Automate it early, it's going to save you a lot of headaches later, even if the process isn't efficient because? Parts are being made just with the game running without you having to CRAFT them all yourself. Makes me glad this game lets you make signs to remind you what a certain group of machines do after you get into automating over a dozen things.

Definitely recommend this game as it definitely is a treat to play with a lot of freedom to play it as YOU want. Just might be just a tad too addictive for it's own good but that's just how good it actually is.

158809072.review:
Satisfactory is an absolute gem in the world of gaming, seamlessly blending elements of exploration, construction, and resource management into an addictive and thoroughly satisfying experience. From the moment you step foot onto the lush, alien planet, you're immediately immersed in a world brimming with potential and possibility.

One of the standout features of Satisfactory is its unparalleled sense of scale. As you embark on your journey to establish a sprawling industrial empire, the vastness of the landscape becomes both your canvas and your challenge. Whether you're constructing towering factories, intricate conveyor belt networks, or sprawling automated production lines, every decision feels consequential, yet immensely rewarding.

The game's visual design is nothing short of breathtaking. From the lush forests teeming with alien flora and fauna to the towering cliffs and cascading waterfalls, every corner of the world is a testament to the developers' attention to detail. The sense of immersion is further enhanced by the dynamic day-night cycle and ever-changing weather patterns, which lend a sense of dynamism and unpredictability to the environment.

But perhaps the most compelling aspect of Satisfactory is its sense of progression. As you unlock new technologies, expand your infrastructure, and optimize your production chains, the sense of accomplishment is palpable. There's a genuine thrill in seeing your humble beginnings evolve into a sprawling industrial complex, teeming with activity and bustling with life.

Yet, despite its complexity, Satisfactory manages to strike a perfect balance between accessibility and depth. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of the genre or a newcomer looking to dip your toes into the world of factory simulation, the game offers a wealth of options and features to suit players of all skill levels.

In conclusion, Satisfactory is a triumph of game design, offering a rich and immersive experience that will keep players coming back for more. With its stunning visuals, satisfying gameplay loop, and boundless sense of exploration, it's a game that deserves a place in every gamer's library. Whether you're building towering skyscrapers or exploring the far reaches of the galaxy, Satisfactory is sure to leave you feeling fulfilled.

Satisfactory, mate, it's like diving into a rabbit hole of automation and resource management. I've clocked a solid 132 hours on Steam, and let me assure you, it's been a rollercoaster of meticulous planning and satisfying achievements.

Now, picture this: you're orchestrating every little detail, tweaking splitters and storage boxes to squeeze out every ounce of efficiency. It's like conducting a symphony of machines, and when it all comes together, mate, it's pure magic.

Sure, there are moments where you wanna throw your keyboard out the window because of some game mechanics trying to stretch out your playtime. But despite those annoyances, the depth of this game is something else. It's not just about building stuff; it's about unraveling the layers of complexity and finding your own creative solutions.

And let's not forget the visuals, mate. Satisfactory is a feast for the eyes, with intuitive controls and settings that let you tailor the experience just the way you like it. Whether you're into building or you just love getting lost in simulations, this game ticks all the boxes.

So, yeah, it's had its ups and downs, but I reckon anyone looking for a gaming experience that's as immersive as it is rewarding should give Satisfactory a whirl. It's a proper gem in the gaming world, no doubt about it.

This is a very interesting but grind heavy game, as expected from factory building games.  

Tips: 

1. Begin organisation early, it's a nightmare to rebuild your factory later on in the game.
2. Early game power is a pain, I recommend heavily focusing on unlocking coal power (space elevator tier 2) as it is a self sustaining energy source unlike the early game biofuel
3. I know I am saying a lot about coal but to have it work efficiently 3 generators to 1 coal miner, and 2 generators to 1 water extractor.
4. Building on foundations for a level factory helps
5. Don't let me dictate how you play the game, these are just some rules I like to follow

Final review: Causes me pain because I have no organisation skills, 10/10

It's a incredibly fun and addicting.

157549206.review:
"Satisfactory" is a masterclass in engineering fantasy, a game that is nothing short of a digital wonderland for the creatively inclined. It's the quintessential lose-yourself kind of experience—relaxing yet addicting, with layers of depth that make it as intricate as it is engaging. The game's core premise is simple: build and automate. Yet, within this simplicity lies a complex ballet of production lines, efficiency optimization, and exploration that can consume countless hours without ever feeling like a grind.

The world of "Satisfactory" is a breathtaking alien landscape, ripe for exploitation and exploration. It's a canvas where your industrial dreams take shape amidst the verdant flora and fauna of an uncharted planet. The sense of scale is immense, and the satisfaction derived from constructing a well-oiled machine of industry across this vast terrain is unparalleled. As you progress, the initial tranquility of manually mining and crafting gives way to the hypnotic hum of conveyor belts and the rhythmic dance of robotic arms—all harmonizing in a symphony of progress.

The game's visual and auditory feedback is a cut above, with every machine and structure offering a satisfying sense of physicality and purpose. The attention to detail is meticulous, from the way resources flow down production lines to the realistic day-night cycle that bathes your factory in the golden hues of dawn or the cool shadows of dusk.

Mod support is nothing short of amazing, breathing new life into the game with each community-created addition. Mods range from quality-of-life improvements to complete gameplay overhauls, ensuring that "Satisfactory" remains endlessly replayable. The developers have fostered a symbiotic relationship with the modding community, resulting in a game that evolves in exciting and unexpected ways.

But it's not just the game itself that's impressive—it's the dev team's commitment to their community. Their transparent communication, regular updates, and genuine passion for their creation shine through in every aspect. They listen, they respond, and they deliver, making "Satisfactory" not just a product but a growing experience shaped by its players.

In conclusion, "Satisfactory" is a game that offers a unique blend of relaxation and complexity, a sandbox of industrial possibilities that can capture the imagination for hours on end. Whether you're a solo player orchestrating a private empire of machines or teaming up with friends to tackle logistical challenges, this game stands as a remarkable achievement in the world of sandbox simulators. It's a testament to the genre and a beacon for future titles to aspire to. "Satisfactory" is, in every sense, a truly satisfying endeavor.

2,386.1 Hours. its obviously yes. Yes I recommend it. 

I have rebuilt a world so many times over. I've created Mega Factories. I've missed zip lines and fallen to my death. I've fired myself like a projectile out of tubes at sonic speed and jet packed across the world. I've killed myself with toxic waste products and been killed by giant corrosive spider-like creatures that are a living nightmare. I've adopted adorable Doggo's and raised them as my sons and daughters to further my own materialistic gains. I've recorded routes for six-wheeled haulers to transport goods across the rough terrain. I have driven a dune buggy into canyon that had no bottom. It's still falling out of space and time I suppose. I've manufactured items, that bend space and time around themselves, by the thousands. And transported them into a giant grinder so i could buy a Boombox and some cassettes. I've stepped off of towering  monoliths of my own creation onto the backs of gentle Leviathans and flown with them like Sebastian did. I've spent mornings in swamps gathering mycelia. Afternoons in jungles buildings railways. Evenings in deserts building Factories on stilts over the dunes. And Nights on the ocean shores constructing ironworks to support immense power generating facilites to keep it all moving. 

But my favourite parts were when the building seemed like enough for the day. And you'd stand on a cliff overlooking the factories, truck stops and train stations listening to the sounds of the wind and trees of the beautiful world that you have marred with industry. Sipping at the coffee in your FICSIT company mug, knowing that tomorrow, you could build something bigger. More efficient. Something concrete. Beautiful and terrifying. Something Rogal Dorn himself would be proud of. 

*sip* - "Yeah. That's the stuff"

P.S. I finally modded my install with some amazing new construction sets. Now it's better than ever. I wish there was a STRONGLY RECOMMENDED button. That edits for you Heyesy. *nods*

139637617.review:
875.4 hours clocked on this game, every world I create, every method I take changes how different my experience is;
World 1;
A spaghetti, disgusting looking factory but hey! I was learning how it all worked.

World 2;
A much neater attempt, making it as far as fuel generation before wanting to change everything about it so I started a new.

World 3;
This is the world where I grinded and grinded, unlocked everything, completed everything, all phases.
Built a giant 100x100 foundation base wrapped around the Space Elevator. But still this world lacked efficiency and neatness.

World 4;
A multiplayer world with my friend in which I forced myself to be neat, tidy and efficient. Also having to explain the games mechanisms to someone helps you understand it even better. I only made it as far as fuel generation as the save was on his PC.

World 5;
This is my current iteration, I've created one of the most efficient worlds I ever thought possible. 
Wanting to get to a level where power would no longer be an issue, I only used the cleanest methods I knew.
I'm now at a point where I'm attempting to make race tracks around some fun parts of the map with moving obstacles and pretty visuals.


This game is more than conveyor belts, there's so many elements to it, you can play it in many ways, whether it's for efficiency, for cleanliness or if it's just for the joy of what the game has to offer.
This has quickly become a staple of my regular plays, the fact it's in early access and has so much to it, makes me excited for what's to come next.

If you are on the fence about buying this game, do it, it's very straightforward and the game helps you every step of the way and then you can start deciding what you want to invest your time and efforts in.

I can't praise this game highly enough, they've gone so hard with the graphics, it's a visually stunning game.
The mechanics are simple and have the potential to be satisfyingly clean depending on your play style.
The enemies add an extra level of challenge and as you upgrade through the tiers you develop new ways of taking them on.

Seriously get this game, it's one of my faves, thank you Coffee Stain and keep up the good work, can't wait to see where you take the game next!

Booted the game up, and was told to set up a little factory.
See this ore vein? Here's a chisel. Don't like the chisel? Here's a workbench to build a little robot miner.
Robot miner taking too long? Here's how you make a powered mining drill and some generators.
By the way, here's a list of things you need to build, and things you can research.
Remember that chisel? Great. Here's a car.
Stop using that car because here's a parachute.
You like the parachute? Too bad it can only go down and not up.
Sike. Here's a jetpack.
Remember that car you built? Here's a train.
Generator? Leaves? More like Biomass. I mean Solid Biomass. I mean Coal. I mean Oil.
That's right, bois, we've found Oil.
Star Spangled Banner Intensifies
Time to liberate this region from the native population.
I have spent several days of my life in this game, and have converted a decent percentage into an artificial, mechanized hellscape from which no life is allowed to flourish.
8/10 until they finish making the game.
Biggest critique would be that some items do not have any actual functionality. Second biggest critique is that I'm impatient.
Buy this game. Play this game. Bully your friends into buying an playing it with you. Raze the beautiful, alien world, and crush it beneath your heel until it begs for death, then take what it has and give nothing back.

70503166.review:
[b]SPOILER-FREE, HONEST REVIEW FROM 600+ HOURS EXPERIENCE ON EPIC[/b]


[b][u]Often-Asked Questions[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] [b]Is there multiplayer?[/b] Yes, up to 4 players, drop-in-drop-out, peer-to-peer. Dedicated Servers for Experimental Version Currently.
[*] [b]Can I crossplay multiplayer with Epic versions of the game?[/b] Yes. And you can link your Steam and Epic friends lists together if you'd like.
[*] [b]How does this game differ from Factorio?[/b]
[list]
[*] Both games have enemies and combat, but you don't need to defend your base in Satisfactory. Think of Satisfactory's challenge more like clearing out biters from strategic resource deposits.
[*] Ore deposits in Satisfactory don't run out like they do in Factorio. The challenge is finding new Iron Deposits so you can make X Motors/minute.
[*] Did I miss something? Oh right, the game has an entire extra THIRD DIMENSION. What more could you possibly want? But the third dimension greatly differentiates the logistics challenges between Factorio and Satisfactory.
[/list]
[*] [b]Are there player "levels"? Can I fall behind my multiplayer friends?[/b] No! When you join a multiplayer game you have access to the technologies unlocked as part of that save. If you join a different game, you'll have access to THAT game's technologies/progress.
[*] [b]Is Early Access buggy?[/b] Bugs are few and far between in the Early Access branch, and the developers have been quick to fix any game-breaking or frustrating bugs as the result of a new update.
[*] [b]Is there a story mode?[/b] Not yet, but the developers have hinted at story elements being added to the game in the future. There IS a tutorial that walks you through concepts in the game, and then progression and exploration is left up to you!
[*] [b]Is there procedural map generation?[/b] No, but [i]that's a good thing[/i]. The continent is 30 square KILOMETERS and every inch was hand-crafted by humans. It takes 18 MINUTES to walk from one corner to the next. Only the most dedicated players will experience the entire planet in a single playthrough, or you could play the game 20 different times for 20 different challenges. And from the moment you land on the planet, you're given an open-world to explore: there are hidden caves, easter eggs (made by the same devs as Goat Simulator, so you know it's gonna be good), optional jumping puzzles, unique resources to collect, alien creatures both friendly and aggressive, and more.
[*] [b]Are there mods for the game?[/b] Yes, there's an growing third-party modding community (I use mods every day to record YouTube tutorial videos). As I write this review, it's not clear if Satisfactory on Steam will use the Steam Workshop, or some other method.
[*] [b]Are there resources to help me if I get stuck or need help?[/b] TONS! There's an official wiki run by the game's developers( https://satisfactory.gamepedia.com ) - careful, there are a lot of spoilers there, I run a YouTube channel with clear, no-BS tips and tricks to help improve your factories( https://www.youtube.com/maxthecatfish ), and there's an active streaming community on Twitch as well ( https://www.twitch.tv/maxthecatfish ).
[*] [b]I Enjoyed X, is Satisfactory for me?[/b]
[list]
      [*] Minecraft w/ Factory Mods - ABSOLUTELY
      [*] Factorio - Yes
      [*] Oxygen Not Included - Probably
      [*] Rimworld/Terraria - Maybe
[/list]
[/list]

[b][u]Long-form Review[/u][/b]
Some background: I've played Factorio, Oxygen Not Included, Rimworld, Terraria, Minecraft, all extensively. I love think-y games like these and others, and Satisfactory provides so much more.

Satisfactory fairly compared to Factorio - both are factory building games that reward players for designing well-tuned factories. Place a miner over some iron, smelt it into iron bars, craft those iron bars into iron rods, turn those rods into screws, combine those screws with some iron plates and you've crafted your first Widget. Now craft hundreds more and combine your widgets into a MEGA WIDGET. So on and so-forth. If that sounds boring to you - picking yourself up by your bootstraps and literally building up civilization from scratch - then you might want to stop reading here. That said, many of you have likely played Factorio, or adjacent games like Oxygen Not Included and are wondering if it's worth letting go of a few more of your [Insert Local Currency Here] for a similar game.

But what sets Satisfactory apart from Factorio is that it brilliantly combines the thoughtful puzzling of a factory builder, with the sheer joy and excitement of an open-world exploration game. In Satisfactory you might spend equal time tuning and designing your factory as you will exploring the continent hunting for unique resources, upgrade modules, and staring at awe at the planet's 20 hand-crafted biomes.

The game gives you the tools be creative with your designs, too! Want to build a factory that looks like a sprawling megacity? Do it! Want to create a regal Grand Central Station for base? Go for it! Want to litter the countryside with phallic effigies?...technically possible! But the beautiful thing is that you don't HAVE to do any of these! Or, you can do them all – whenever you want. The game as it stands is entirely open-ended and relatively stress-free, from the moment you gain control of your character you can do whatever you’d like, go wherever you’d like, and that freedom is…exhilarating!

If you simply want a factory building experience without the explorative aspects of the game, you can have that. If you want a sandbox to build in then – in all honesty - Minecraft might be more your style -  but you can ALSO accomplish that in Satisfactory with the right mindset. The game provides both mental and dexterity challenges but you can bypass each of these in creative ways using the tools at your disposal in ways that feel authentic to the gameplay experience!

But the game does have a tendency to feel lonely. You’re the sole human inhabitant of this far-off planet. And other than snuggling with your pack of “Lizard Doggos” or the voice of A.D.A.  – the player’s snarky AI assistant  - in your helmet, you’re on your own.

Unless…you bring some friends! Satisfactory offers drop-in-drop-out peer-to-peer multiplayer across both Steam and Epic versions of the game and the developers have mentioned that Dedicated Servers will be added to the game sometime…soon™. Until then, up to four pioneers can build together, fight monsters together, plan factories together, rebuild factories together, yell at each other for rebuilding that part of the factory without consulting the others, delete a pivotal conveyor belt out of spite for being berated by your friends, then go off and form a NEW factory, with NEW and BETTER friends who know that conveyor belts should be build at 90 degree angles and how DARE you even CONSIDER using the default recipe for crafting screws when the steel screw recipe is obviously superior in both throughput and resource requ-

On second thought, maybe the single-player experience is best for you. I kid, of course – it’s a nice change of pace to experience the full breadth of the game with your friends. And for the most part the multiplayer experience in Satisfactory is smooth. The game IS still in early access and there are a number of known bugs and issues, but all-in-all the game has been relatively bug-free and that’s an accomplishment worth praising these days. The game's team is incredibly communicative , and the community has responded in-kind with community-driven resources like satisfactory-calculator.com and the ficsit.app unofficial modding community. 

If you enjoy think-y challenges and building structures in a massive open-world, you'll enjoy Satisfactory. If you want an FPS-forward adventure game, look elsewhere. But if you'd like some factory building mixed in with planet exploration mixed in with a bit of combat, you should absolutely consider buying Satisfactory.

92059449.review:
I thought this was going to be a game only about optimizing your factory in an essentially sandbox environment. What I got was a rich game with a very well designed alien world to explore, with subtle messages about environmentalism and the beauty of nature contrasting with the efficiency of machinery.  There are literally breathtaking vistas, vast beautiful cave networks, impossible alien landforms, and completely on point music and sound direction.  The slightly sinister feeling nature of your FICSIT overlords lends some deep nuance; what are you actually doing here? What role are you playing, and who are you serving?

I'm not an optimizer. I enjoy efficiency, but I'm not one to overdesign to get there, so my bases end up having a naturalistic "base camp" feel, while my friends are building towering factories with rows and rows of machinery. I'm really glad to say, this game supports both playstyles fantastically. I see my friends having a blast designing and organizing monolithic black cubes full of layers and layers of machinery, whereas I love spreading out and nestling my machines in with the trees and cliffs.

The one thing I would dock this game for is that the ecosystem feels too player-focused. I want to see predators chasing prey and fighting other predators for territory. I want to see animals that consume resources, and possibly animals that caretake and develop their own resources as well. This might not be the game for that, and if you're also wanting to see an alien ecosystem spring to life, I highly recommend Subnautica. However, I can't deny the intentional design I feel in segments of this game. Collecting power slugs to me feels like collecting Missile Packs in Metroid. They are usually placed in areas that have a similar challenge feel to them, and are a wonderful reward for exploration.  I can't wait to find out what Somersloops and Mercer Spheres are for, because they provide such an intense incentive to explore that I think is missing from some games like this.

There are still bugs and glitches, particularly with enemy AI. It's very rudimentary and when you master kiting enemies, they don't provide that much of a challenge, even with the Xeno-zapper.  It's only when they congregate and team up against you that they feel like a challenge.  On the other hand, that complexity is used to great effect in the placement of hostile mobs today, so I can't knock the simplistic AI too much because it combines and scales difficulty fairly well, despite the somewhat limited toolkit for designing these encounters.

Also, placing the Space Elevator is a religious experience. I don't care how jaded you are, it's a masterstroke of technology that that sequence plays out so organically and dynamically. You really *feel* the scale of the structure, and it changes the skyline forever.

I feel like there are still some quality of life hiccups around inventory management. As an FPS player, I often find myself hitting the number row to switch my in-hand equipment, only to remember too late that those hotkeys are for your building toolbelt.  I'd love a way to switch between modes, even if it just means holding shift while pressing a number gets the build mode quickbar, and just pressing the number equips a new item to your hand slot.  On the other hand, there are some very nice Quality of Life touches that I appreciate once I've gotten used to the quirks of this game.  Actually placing buildings is decently streamlined, and I appreciate the way building off of foundations allows for a very granular angling. Once you're started building a foundation to fit the area, the 90-degrees snap-to-grid functionality feels very useful.  The only complaint I have here is the sometimes janky feeling of trying to get conveyors to snap together. It can be very finicky about what counts as a valid angle, and the feedback isn't always clear about why a conveyor can't be constructed. "Encroaching others' area" ends up being a somewhat frustrating exercise of shimmying things around in minute ways just fiddling to get the lines all connected.

Honestly, though, the game is beautiful enough to warrant the price tag. I don't just mean graphics specifications and technical aptitude. The design of the game's assets and their placement creates spellbinding beauty. The way biomes flow into each other feels extremely organic and immersive, and I've never seen transitions so smooth in any other game. It feels like it surpasses Breath of the Wild in this respect, and some of this may be because setting this on an alien world helps smooth over any strangeness in geology or botany that would subtly break immersion otherwise.  There are so many systems in this game to become familiar with, and the tech tree feels so rewarding and rich that it compels me to develop more and more.  All in all, this is genius design. Mad respect.

105877410.review:
This is one of the finest games I've ever played, for a number of reasons. The main ones are:

1. Well-scaled factory sim. The game lulls you in with the perfect amount of simplicity at the start to make every added bit of complexity make sense in the larger scale of the game. Often factory sims drop you in, teach you a couple of things, then let you get overwhelmed with the scale of the project in front of you. I felt this particularly with Dyson Sphere Project - the game tells you what the endgame is, then gets you started on a scale that seems so impossibly small you don't feel like you're making progress. It's not a bad game at all, but I think the drip-feeding of ever-increasing complexity, depth, and scale make Satisfactory a real winner in this regard.

2. The first person perspective is a terrific choice. Often the top-down/isometric view factory sims seem too remote, too abstract. Being on the ground and walking around your factory makes it really rewarding to indulge in...

3. your architectural dreams. The game is all about systems planning, throughput efficiency, and logistics, and you can indulge in all of that without ever dressing up your factories or making them look nice. But if you like designing a brutalist monolith as an homage to Arne Jacobsen then this is possible. The game has plenty of scope for aesthetic sculpting.

Drawbacks: not many, but I do hope they will be implementing some story elements, and the game can feel a bit lonely and empty of purpose as a result of this I think. Purpose is provided by your own ambitions and by finessing your production lines to achieve the next level of complexity - this is fine, but it would be nice to have some flavour or unexpected reasons to adapt production from time to time. Special projects or the like.

70690339.review:
[h2] No, this is not 3D Factorio. It's a similar game focused on building and exploration. Yes, it already has enough content to play it for more than a hundred hours, even if only by doing a single playthorugh. Yes, it's already worth the price if you are into this kind of gameplay. If you want more details, read the rest of the review. [/h2]

I should preface this by saying that I already have played multiple hours of Satisfactory (Around 200-300) on EGS. This is a review of somebody who has seen everything the game has to offer at the moment, but still wants to play more of it which is clearly indicated by the 25 hours of playtime I already put into the Steam version. God, this is turning into an addiction. Anyway, on with the review: 

First things first, stop calling this 3D Factorio. It's not that, and it simply leads to hundreds of people forming false expectations and complaining about the game not playing like Factorio. Really, you don't say? It's also important to understand that when deciding whether this is a game for you. If you're simply deciding based on you liking Factorio then be careful, this game play way different and has a different focus. So, consider yourself warned.

Okay, so what is Satisfactory? It's an open world factory building/exploration game. There is currently no precise end goal (more on that later), but the overarching objective is to automate gathering of resources and materials production by setting up networks of construction building that will allow you to produce materials you will need to unlock more buildings and ever more complicated materials to craft, which will lead to bigger and more complex building networks, and so on. Eventually you will be forced to expand your factory to really big sizes and transport resources from long distances away to keep up with the demand. It's the same basic formula as games like Factorio, but here it plays out a little bit different. I will focus on these since those are at the same time some of the game's biggest strengths, and the things that may put off those people who expected an experience more akin to Factorio, since so many people are overly fond of describing this game as "3D Factorio"...

First major difference is the map. There is a single map and no random map generation. Sucks right? Not really. The map is really, big. And I mean REALLY big. Big enough that you will not even explore a third of it on a normal playthrough, and you will expand to even less places. Also, it's a hand crafted, 3D map, which means it's infinitely times more interesting to explore and work with than any randomized map you could ever hope for. It;s also a 3D map, so there is elevation and multiple layers to work with, cave systems, huge mountains, all of this means there is an insane amount of space to explore and work with. And you are given 4 starting locations to work with, which easily translates to at least 4 unique playthroughs thanks to the sheer size and amount of things the map has to offer. This is in my opinion a huge improvement over randomly generated maps, that never really feel unique from one another after a single playthrough. The technology is not there yet.

Second major difference would be the focus on exploration. Unless you find yourself one of the popular "best" starting spots, you will have to very quickly start exploring and looking for more resources. Most places you will find will not give you enough nodes to supply enough throughput to run even an early game factory (unless you go really small), so you will have to look for more even early on. There are some biomes and spots that bend that rule to various degrees, but most novice players won't know about them, and I encourage to avoid them if it's your first playthrough. Aside from resources there are other very useful things to look for: there are collectibles such as various plants that heal you, power slugs that can be researched and turned into items that allow to overclock your production buildings (necessary if you want to go for maximum efficiency), wrecks that have a lot of free resources spread around them (sometimes really valuable and high tier ones) that also contain hard drives, which are essential items that let you unlock alternative recipes for materials for even more efficiency and possibilities. There are also roaming monsters that you can kill for their drops that can be later researched and used to make some unique items, and rare resources that are normally used to craft things later in the game, but if you find some of them earlier you can use them to make some really useful and powerful upgrades that will massively help you in both building your factory and exploration. So yes, exploration is a REALLY important aspect of the game, if you really dedicate yourself to it you could spend almost as much time on it as on building your factory. And thanks to the map being so big and hand crafted there is definitely a lot to explore.

Third major difference is how it plays. It's a very relaxing game, the only stress you'll experience is going to be moment to moment combat with roaming monsters, and getting stressed by trying to figure out why your factory is not working as it should and where is that one conveyor belt you forgot to connect. There is no immediate danger to your factory, there is no base defence from the enemies, there are no survival elements like food or water. It's a game purely focused on building and exploration, sprinkled with some combat when exploring or expanding into remote locations. Once kill all the monsters in the area, it's yours to explore and exploit, and if you build powered infrastructure then the monsters will stop respawning in the vicinity. And if you read this and think that it means it has less going on for it than the other games that have some kind of base defence elements, then you're wrong. As I already said, exploration is a major part of the game, something I haven't seen been done this well and to such extent in any games from this "factory builder" genre. Building your bases is also a much bigger and more involving task here. The third dimension is not simply just a gimmick. It's a major factor to consider when setting up your bases. Elevation plays a huge role and can be a real challenge to overcome. Sure, you can build everything on the ground like you would in a 2D game, but even then the ground is not flat. There are hills, valleys, natural obstacles, big rocks that you can't really get rid off, cliffs, water... the game really wants to make it as difficulty to build big bases on the ground. As you would expect from a random planet you were just dropped of on, it's not very well prepared for mass Industrialisation. That's why building vertically is such a big element of this game and the game gives you plenty of tools to accomplish this. Moreover, the game gives you a lot of things to spice up the building process and accomplish things that are simply not possible in a 2D game. Do you want to run multiple conveyor belts on top of one another? There are tools for that. Do you want to close off your factory with walls and roofs so you don't have to look at the horrible spaghetti you have made? No problem. Maybe you should now mounts those conveyor belts on the walls you just made? Or maybe through them? The game has a lot of tools to make the building process interesting and not feel like you're bound to the game's rules. There are always multiple ways to accomplish the same goal.

I could go on for a couple more paragraphs, but I ran out of characters. If you read through all of it, you already know if it's a game fr you or not. If you didn't, then just read the header and watch some gameplay to get the idea. If you have a specific question, you can comment under my review and I will try to answer. Hope you had a nice read, and if you decide to purchase the game, I hope you have as much fun as I do.

81523148.review:
Hello there!

I would like to share my experience of this game in which I spend over 220 hours and still counting.

When I've seen the trailers and some gameplay on YouTube, I honestly have not been convinced and thought it is going to be as complex and simulating as Space Engineers for example.
After a video from LetsGameItOut, I've been like: "Uhh, that game is on sale, lets give it a try".
And boy, those were probably the best €20 I spend this year.

This game catches you instantly. The graphics are very nice and you can see that the map is created with a lot of love and attention in detail.
The Gameplay is awesome. You have got a mixture of exploring (combined with a very minimal amount of survival), factory building, planning and optimizing (especially for people with the same OCD as I have). 

Due to the excellent Tutorial, you get a nice start into the game and instantly start to optimize, research and explore.
New buildings and technologies can be researched due to payments via produced parts. The small steps within the Tiers aren't that hard to achieve but the bigger Tier Steps (3 - Space Elevator Steps) are more difficult to achieve and are demanding a not so small factory.  

As you can see in the trailers you can build your factory with your own style. Personally, I'm more the OCD guy, but you can create your own conveyor belt spaghetti if you want. Nobody is forcing you to build in a certain way. All that creating, building, planning and optimizing can be done in your own pace. It's not unusual for me to try a highly praised game and get bored after an hour or two.

73647141.review:
For context: I am an engineer by profession.

My first impression of this game was: "Oh cool. It's like smooth modded Minecraft. Its essentially Minecraft 2"

My first impression was woefully misplaced.

This game does not deserve to be called the second Minecraft, as it does not deserve to be in Minecraft's shadow.

This game is an amazing giant that should be in no other's shadow.

I can not explain how much fun this game is for me. Making plans, backup plans and backup backup plans. Milking every percentage of efficiency. Seeing how a collection of small subsystems perfectly function together as one mighty machine.

The small details the game gives attention to is also amazing, like how your workbench heats up from hammering, or how miners keep replacing shafts as though the keep going deeper and deeper.

For a game still in early release it has displaced mountains some AAA titles still need to realise they have.

There is some critique though. The clipping of conveyers, pipes and surfaces is still a headache, though minor. But this game still is in early access so its not a monorail smash.

20/10 would recommend (Yes 20/10, I found powerslugs specially for this review)

76523662.review: I've always been quite cynical of Coffee Stain Studios, writing them off as the developers of the 2014 YouTube sensation and blatant cash grab Goat Simulator. When I first encountered Satisfactory, I was extremely skeptical of the flashy E3 trailers I was presented with, yet I added the game to my wishlist nonetheless. While the overwhelmingly positive reviews and flashy promos enticed me, I kept the game on my wishlist for months without any intent to really buy the game in the foreseeable future. I finally got around to buying Satisfactory with some leftover Steam wallet funds a couple days ago, and I cannot stress how fabulous this game is. The fundamentals and mechanics of Factorio with the worldbuilding and immersion of Subnautica make for a truly incredible experience. Besides being one of the prettiest games I've ever played, it's also among the most intellectually stimulating games in my steam library. In the two days I've owned it, I've clocked over 30 hours in it and don't plan to slow down any time soon. Even when I'm not playing the game, my brain is contemplating how to optimize my factory's efficiency and my production rates. This game is so good that I bought it a day before it went on sale, and I wasn't even mad that I could've saved 10 bucks. This game is worth every cent I paid for it and nothing less.

81142444.review:
After playing so many Early Access games, I was a little leery about this one. Factory building? That just sounds boring. After we watched the Youtube channel Let's Game It Out and laughing ourselves sick, and finding this has multiplayer, my husband and I decided to give it a shot, and at least it would kill a few hours.

This game is honestly one of the better, if not best early access games I've played. Yes, the multiplayer is buggy (don't bother with transportation, network issues cause people to not be where they look like, etc) but it's a very solid base, a lot of it does work and works very smoothly. There's so many early access games that have a ton of ideas and stretch themselves so thin, and you wonder when they're going to add any depth to it... and they don't, and you end up with a 2 mile long puddle. It has everything it said, but it's still a puddle. Satisfactory has a surprising amount of depth, even if you don't like the building (and are playing with someone that does), you can still help with gathering items, scouting, placing beacons, killing the local fauna, etc.

There is no plot in the game as of yet, but there's a ton of little touches that I really enjoy. The fact there's a wrench keychain on the sword, and another on one of the other weapons (I think the rebar gun), and several other things just give much more life to a faceless, voiceless character then expected. I mean, each time you pick up a new tool, your character looks at it (and often fiddles with something, like the keychain), and that is just... enjoyable to see. It shows the character you are is a person, not just a robot for the player to pilot around.

The world feels like an actual world too. Yes, the biomes are fairly small and close together, but they flow into each other really well, and it feels like a properly done, alive world.

This is one of those games I get excited when I see an announcement from the devs, because I'm looking forward to more of the game, not the feeling of "Oh, another DLC to add to the pile" or "Oh goody, an update, I need to stop playing for a week so they can hotfix everything AGAIN." It's just... nice. It's a nice, colorful, fun multiplayer game and I wish there was more games I could say that about.

I want a FICSIT coffee mug too. They should get on that.

70508740.review:
So I started playing Satisfactory when it first launched a couple years ago on the Store-that-shall-not-be-named-on-Steam, and have a couple hundred hours in it over the past two years.

This game is a mash-up of [i]Factorio[/i] and [i]Subnautica[/i], with plenty of good (and bad) features from both, but with amazing devs it is really shaping up to be a fun game.

[h1]Game Features[/h1]

✔️ GAME LOOP: 
The entire loop is based on producing items with your factory that unlock the next tier of items, which will make life easier but also go up in difficulty to produce.  As you expand production and unlock new tech, you'll be refactoring your base and traveling out further for rarer resources.  Overall, this loop *just works*, and fairly fun and balanced.

✔️ AESTHETIC:  
For EA, Satisfactory is super polished.  Yes, your conveyor belts will clip through things and you'll find bugs, but overall it's a beautiful world to explore and steal resources from.  The design is less like Factorio's diesel-punk (e.g. Wall-E) and more like Subnautica's shiny-future (e.g. Eve). 

❌ ANIMAL BALANCE: 
The animals and their spawns are way too aggressive currently.  You can clear out an area only to have to do it again a few minutes later, and the weapons you get do not give you much advantage.  It makes expansion more of a chore than a fun challenge.

[h1]Similarities to Factorio[/h1]

✔️ THE FACTORY MUST GROW: 
Explore, expand, and exploit an alien world is the main theme of this game and it's just as fun as it is in Factorio.  You will build, refactor, and build again parts of your supply chains, but each time it feels rewarding as you continue to unlock tiers.

✔️ THE THIRD DIMENSION: 
Factorio is an automation game, but the loop boils down to a two-dimensional puzzle of belts, assemblers, and inserters.  Satisfactory keeps that loop but moves it into the third dimension.  There's no inserters - belts connect everything - but you'll be solving some of the same problems as Factorio just  in three dimensional space.

✖️ NO BASE DEFENSE:
Native life doesn't attack your factory if you grow too fast or too greedily.  In fact, the factory itself can't really take damage, so there isn't any lose condition (yet anyways).  You can just casually build and expand a factory, which is still fun but lacks a late game challenge.

✖️ DOWNSIZED PRODUCTION: 
Satisfactory takes a different approach to the massive amounts of resources that Factorio has, and has significantly scaled down production.  For example, with each mine you will be constructing one miner and six smelters, as opposed to Factorio's dozen miners and four dozen smelters.  Buildings as more expensive though to compensate, and it balances out.

✖️ INFINITE RESOURCES: 
Once you build a mine in Satisfactory, it will produce resources indefinitely.  This makes Satisfactory more a game about managing rates of production rather than the additional inventory management that comes from bursts or busts in your supply chain.  Also any lack of power shuts down the whole factory instead of simply slowing it, which makes it even easier to plan production lines.

❌ AUTOMATION NOT INCLUDED:  
With Factorio, you could automate [i]everything[/i] including the assemblers, and even go most of the game without crafting anything if you chose to.  Satisfactory, unfortunately, only lets you automate crafted item construction, not buildings or foundations, which have to be all hand-built by you.

❌ BELTS [strike]VS BOTS[/strike]:  
This is the biggest difference, IMO.  There are no bots in Satisfactory, and no blueprint feature as of yet.  There's that sweet spot in Factorio where you start to scale up with bots and your factory grows exponentially, but that's not here with Satisfactory.  It gets really annoying when you have a nice plate-assembly configuration you want to copy somewhere else, but you have to build it all again from scratch.


[h1]Similarities to Subnautica:[/h1]

✔️ LUSH ALIEN WORLD:  
The aspect of exploring an exotic alien world full of danger makes Subnautica one of the better games out there, and Satisfactory has gone this same route too with multiple biomes.  There isn't the unending procedural generation like Factorio, and you have to plan your expansion accordingly, but Satisfactory scratches that exploration itch.

✔️ MEGAFAUNA: 
Big alien creatures roam the planet with you, and sometimes get in your way.  They're mostly cosmetic right now and not that dangerous (yet?), but as for the giant spiders they can go **** themselves.  Late game resources are especially challenging to extract from a very dangerous biome.

✔️ RESEARCH TREES: 
There are multiple paths you can take to acquire new tech and toys, either through the main game, scanning native life/resources, finding crashed ship hard drives, or grinding out fun bucks by trading items for company goods.  It's novel way to go about researching different branches and I hope they don't drop them.

✖️ BASE BUILDING:  
Everything in Satisfactory is built the same way you built bases in Subnautica, with your little sci-fi projector thing, but on steroids.  It can build copies of the same building pretty quickly, given if you have the resources to do it, but only one type of building at a time.  It takes some handling to get used to laying foundations at scale but they have a snap grid to help.

❌ SENSE OF TERROR: 
Satisfactory is really missing that thrill of being alone and feeling hunted, that Subnautica captures so well as a survival horror game.  You can argue that's not the point of Satisfactory (it's not), but Subnautica fans will not find it if they're looking for it.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

Overall, if you're a fan of either Factorio or Subnautica, you'll probably find something to like in this game.  The devs have done a good job of making good, functional releases and their community manager guy is awesome.  The game is definitely justified at this price.

[i]Note for New players[/i]:  Check out the [i]Let's Game It Out[/i] YT videos to see how not to play the game.  Also, when picking a biome to start, the Grass Fields has the most room to easily build but by mid-late game you'll be incredibly far from rare resources.  Given how much of a chore it is to expand and transport long distances, you're better off starting in the Northern Forest for now.
