71932670.review:
[h1] Satisfactory is a first-person open-world, where the player can build factories all over the distant planet which is presented as a huge handcrafted 30+ square kilometers map. The player can explore the planet alone or with their friends, producing new materials, and building new factories over and over again. [/h1]  

[b] Pros: [/b]

+ Satisfying gameplay about building factories and designing an efficient production
+ It’s extremely addictive, the neverending feeling of “just one more thing”
+ Decent amount of materials, productions, and pieces of machinery 
+ Amazing graphics
+ A huge handcrafted map to explore 
+ A huge replayability value
+ Atmospheric music that perfectly fits the game
+ Constant updates from the developers

[b] Cons: [/b]

- The game can behave a bit weird in multiplayer mode, keep in mind, that it’s still under development
- Lots of important and needed features that are still absent 
- Minor bugs here and there 

I must say, that I am a huge fan of Satisfactory. I am playing this game since March 2019 and it feels like I have no plans on stopping, this game never bored me since then. What is really important to say here, that I was never a fan of building games, where the player has to explore, craft, survive, and all stuff like this, this was never my kind of thing. 

So when I purchased Satisfactory, it was more like an experiment for me, just to see what’s people are talking about. Plus I was really hooked with its trailer and screenshots, everything seemed there extremely attractive. 

And to be honest, I fell in love with this game instantly. What I really liked there, that this game doesn’t put any pressure on the player. There is no such thing as “right” or “wrong” in Satisfactory - you can’t make any mistakes in this game. The player is free to do whatever they want and to construct their factory or anything else just the way they see it.

Satisfactory is all about the player’s creativity, it’s all about the satisfying building experience, this game is absolutely stress-free and a perfect choice for the players who are looking for the games, where they don’t have to worry about their score, gaming skill or how good they are comparing to other players. 

[b] Story [/b]

There is no such thing as a proper story in Satisfactory as of June 2020, however, the developers promise to add the story in the future updates. The basic idea of the game is that the protagonist lands on the unknown alien planet called Massage-2(AB)b and starts building there a new factory with complex productions. 

[b] Gameplay [/b]

The game starts with an understanding that the player is completely alone on a pretty big map and now he has to start building the factory here. The protagonist has basic instruments to build the main base and a small yet efficient weapon to defend himself from the enemies on this planet. Satisfactory explains the basics of the game on a pretty understandable level, so every single kind of player can get into the game easily.

At first, the player has to build the main base and then find his first iron nod to start gathering its materials. From this point, the whole game starts to unfold itself when the player starts to build long-chained productions to produce different kinds of materials, searching for various types of resources and thinking about how to build them all in the most logical way. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2149424031

There is a tier system in Satisfactory that lets the player unlock technologies and new possibilities to expand their factory. This helps a lot for the player to get into the whole idea of the game gradually so by the time the player hits the final tier, they will be prepared and know how everything works and what kind of instruments they have in their arsenal.

During this unlocking process, the player has to build the space elevator, which has to be connected to the production chain. This allows the player to send requested materials to the company, the main protagonist works for to unlock the next set of tiers. Unlocking all the available tiers will take a while. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2124300767

After unlocking every single tier of production, the players are free to do whatever they feel like. Satisfactory’s only limit is your imagination and you can’t do something completely wrong here, the freedom is yours. You can focus on building a mega factory, think about new projects to start or explore the whole map to make sure that every single node is occupied - this is all up to your choice and this is simply amazing. 

There are a few types of enemies in Satisfactory that can be a bit dangerous in the early game but once the player unlocks more powerful weapons, they won’t be that dangerous at all. To be honest, I still don’t understand why they even exist in the game, because they don’t do any harm to the player’s constructions and they don’t any challenge to the gameplay with its existing. My only guess is that the developers plan to give them a much important role in future updates. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2124299500

The game can be played in both solo and multiplayer modes up to 4 players. However, the multiplayer mode is much bugged than solo and it can be a bit unstable in terms of internet connections.   

It’s important to understand that the game is still under development and it’s constantly updating every few months adding new features, possibilities, and fixing minor bugs and issues. But even for the fact that this game is still in Early Access, it looks absolutely gorgeous.    

[b] Graphics [/b]

The game looks amazing, with all those beautiful colorful landscapes, trees, and plants all over the alien planet. The map is divided into four different zones each with its own atmosphere, nature and overall feeling. In general, I can say that this game brings the most outstanding graphics I have ever seen in base building games. 

[b] Sound [/b] 

Music in Satisfactory is something I can talk about for hours because it’s magnificent, it definitely fits the atmosphere of the whole game. Considering the fact that the whole game is a pretty chilling and meditative experience, the soundtrack of this game definitely plays along greatly. If you ever feel like you are tired of the in-game music, I strongly recommend you to look for the playlist in Spotify called Satisfactory - Ambient Soundtrack.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

Satisfactory is the game that I am playing since it has been launched back in March 2019. Frankly speaking, I am that kind of person who gets bored with the games pretty quickly but this is not the case. I always come back to Satisfactory to build something else, to check new updates, to play with my friends, or to start a brand new map, considering all the mistakes, I’ve done in the past. This is a perfect sandbox base-building game that is constantly updating that I can recommend to everyone who is looking for a chilling and meditative experience. 

I am in love with Satisfactory.

[b] Enjoy! [/b]

I take a long sip of coffee and let the warm liquid run down my throat at 30m3/min. I look out over a once beautiful landscape, teaming with life and vegetation, to a sight that can only be described as a travesty against nature itself. Dark smoke billows from my highly inefficient coal plants, sputtering and bellowing large black clouds of satisfying CO2. All while barely a train derail away from my inhabitable nuclear plant. I wipe the film of toxic mist from my visor, nod my head, and smile. This is my masterpiece. This is my home.

86293058.review:
Satisfactory builds on what roped me into Factorio and expands it into a fully 3D map. Initially, there are hurdles to overcome (if you are coming from a top down automation game) but once you get your brain wrapped around the change to vertical building, it becomes yet another game that will steal hours upon hours from you. 

Graphically it is beautiful. You get a full sense of being in an alien world with enough recognizable things to stay grounded in reality. As with most automation games, you'll start over several times (if not more) as you build yourself into a corner with little room to expand. Which is something that this game demands...space. Lots of it. You'll dedicate entire plots of land to a single item. You'll advance and realize you did it all wrong and now you can't get part A to building B without building the most inefficient and ugly belt system to get there. 

If you favor aesthetics over function, prepare to have your brain fried as you try to figure out what you need and where it needs to go before you build it. But there are other ways to transport items. You get trucks of a couple sizes, a variety of belts and poles to align them as you see fit and a train system that will put your engineering chops to the test. 

As far as adversity, there isn't much of it. Some of the wildlife is aggressive but nothing that requires you to be a master at reflexes. Most of your time will be spent with a digital cup of coffee in hand, staring out at what you are building and wondering how you are going to get the things you need at not only the right place, but at the right ratios as well. Exploration is where the real danger is especially if you are like me and don't look before you leap. Many a canyon have welcomed my lifeless body because "oh there is something glowing there!" took priority over "is there a giant cliff here?". The progression through the tiers of items is good and every new milestone reached allows you to make much needed updates to your factory to improve throughput, tighten grid placement, and traverse the world quicker and with fewer speed bumps. So you'll start with hand tools and eventually be able to jetpack to new (previously unattainable) areas. It feels organic and makes for a fun and engaging game curve to follow. 

There are some quality of life things that I'd like to see such as more efficient ways to build massive structures rather than one piece at a time, labeling of containers to know what's in them from a distance, and a more robust netcode (MP games can get violently choppy if you are playing with anyone not local to you). 

One major con is that the map is singular. There is no randomization and once you have explored it all, that is it. You'll learn where nodes are and it does pull some of the exploration awe out of the game. But you are too busy to worry about that. The factory must grow. 

All in all, this is a fantastic building/logistic game and it continues to suck hours from my life.

71213682.review:
Factorio is better, but hear me out!

TLDR: the game can be frustrating at first, but gets increasingly better as you progress and learn.

It is a different game and should not be compared to Factorio, but you just can't help but compare it. When I started it I got rather disappointed, borderline quitting, because I tried to play it like Factorio, I expected it to be Factorio, but things that worked there didn't work here. But as I progress through the game and unlock things, as I learn the differences and adapt my new ways, I fell in deep love with Satisfactory.

- I got frustrated to hand feed biomass to my burners - until I unlocked coal.
- I missed the gridlines, hand placed buildings didn't align, factory looked ugly - until I learned about foundations (it allows snapping to grids).
- All buildings looked the same, it was impossible to navigate in your factory - until I unlocked color-coding.
- I hated to move across my factory jumping over my endless belts - so I learned to place them above my head.
- Main Bus is not the best idea here, the game encourages you to use automated vehicles instead.
- I wanted an infinite flat surface to build, I disliked the idea to squeeze my factory around irregular terrain - until I discovered that 3rd dimension opens up endless possibilities. The ability to build vertical is the strongest side of this game and looking back at Factorio I'm gonna miss this feature a lot.

The game is beautiful (graphics resemble Subnautica for some reason), but animations are beyond awesome! After over 100 hours I still enjoy them. And I don't mean that Factorio is ugly, it is not.

Exploration is a huge part of the game, a big part of the tech tree is dedicated to help you with exploration. But on the other hand we have a hand-made map here. Will it be fun to explore it for the tenth time? Especially with online maps with pin-pointed locations?

The resources are infinite here, they don't expire. You still need to find new ones as your factory grows.

There is no pollution, no tower defense. You only fight creatures while exploring the world.

The game is still unfinished, there is no end game. And the end game worries me the most. I haven't reached it yet, but I wonder if there is a reason to motivate me to endlessly expand my factory? In Factorio we had endless research to gradually increase our capabilities, I don't think we have it here. Yeah, I can earn the in-game currency to buy things I don't need, but I don't feel it is enough.

But so far I love this game, I became obsessed with it. Every night I cannot sleep because I think of ways to improve my factory, every morning I wake up with a new vision to tear everything down and rebuild. Sometimes I cannot wait till morning and get up midnight to try new solutions. And if I successfully fall asleep I have endless walkways and belts in my nightmares :)

Yes, I recommend this game. You can't expect it to beat Factorio (the second best rated game on steam), but oh god it is awesome!

----

Update after 200+ hours:

My fears of end game hasn't been realized this yet. After I unlocked all techs and alternative recipes, now I need to completely rebuild my factory, with nuclear power and railway network bringing resources from all over the map. I expect this project take me a month or two.

Also I changed my mind and I'm building the main bus :)

People commenting about me comparing it to Factorio: yes, I said one should not compare it, BUT YOU JUST CAN'T HELP BUT COMPARE IT. https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/somebody-can-t-help-doing-something

90240024.review:
WARNING. This game is pure drug. Don't buy unless You have no kids, no wife and You have a lot free time. I mean thousands of hours.

Your brain will turn into a machine calculating the optimal use of all available resources on the map, there are hundreds of them and each discovery brings new threats from the beautiful mother nature. At some point You may experience unexpected dreams about high tech and well tuned factories.

Early Access in this case means something similar to never ending story. When You think "I have done everything" new update shows up and You're starting doing mess again.

I can only have reservations about the multiplayer mode, where there are funny glitches, disappearing objects, self-propelled vehicles, lack of character synchronization, etc. However, this does not prevent having continuous fun in the co-op mode.

I hope You like it so much as I did.

EDIT: Still thinking of buying it? Don't think, just do it. U8 changed a lot, it's now Unreal Engine 5 with Lumen effects, devs are pushing forward to get final product release. Join the party!
